page.text: Public Hearing and possible motion regarding Rezone #14CZ17, Greenmoor PUD Plan 50.2 acres located at 7616
and 7716 Green Level Church Road from Rural Residential (RR) to Planned Unit Development Conditional Zoning
The Planning Board reviewed this item at their November 10, 2014 and recommended approval.
Planning Board Report to Town Council
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
All property owners within three hundred (300) feet of this rezoning have been notified per UDO Section 2.2.11
2030 Land Use Map: MD (Medium Density Residential)
the Holt Residential Subdivision) Pulte Home
The site consists of two parcels totaling 50.5 acres and includes trees, fields, and a stream. North of the site is
the approved Holt Subdivision by Pulte Homes Corporation that has not been developed at this time. Pulte
Homes plans on building both subdivisions as one development to be known as Greenmoor PUD. The NC 540
Hwy is located east of the site.
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
The applicant is proposing a PUD Plan that includes the following uses:
The residential use includes the architecture conditions as follows:
1. Vinyl siding is not permitted; however, vinyl windows, decorative elements and trim are permitted.
2. A crawl space, basement or turned-down slab foundation is required with a minimum of twenty (20”)
inches from grade to front elevation finished floor. On the front elevation, the twenty (20”) inches will
have masonry such as brick or stone. The side and rear of the house does not have to meet the twenty
3. Garage doors must be painted to match the house trim or siding color and have either windows,
decorative details, or carriage style adornments.
4. Homes shall include a front porch or stoop with a minimum depth of four (4’) feet.
5. The garage cannot protrude more than one foot from either the front facade or porch, except that the
garage may protrude up to five feet from the front façade or porch with the inclusion of windows in the
garage door and one architectural feature such as a variation in roof form, a balcony, a trimmed
window or a decorative vent over the door area to minimize the impact of the garage façade.
6. The roof for primary structures (i.e., excluding porches, bay windows, etc.) shall be pitched at 5:12 or
7. The side of a corner lot home that is visible from a public street must include two of the following
b) Masonry for at least 10% of wall area
c) Variation in siding material pattern for at least 20% of the wall area.
d) Bay, transom or casement window.
8. For homes that back up to a perimeter road (i.e., Green Level Church Road or Roberts Road), the rear
windows must include four (4”) trim and the rear roof must include variation in the roofline such that
no rear roofline is identical to the roofline on either side of it. This can be accomplished thru the
variation of roof type, pitch, direction, or height, and/or the addition of features such as dormers or
The proposed maximum height is 36 feet. The maximum density proposed is 3.56 units per acre which is a
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner

text.b: Buffers, Resource Conservation Area, Natural Resource and Environment

page.text: The Resource Conservation Area (RCA) requirement for the proposed PUD Plan is 25 percent or 12.5 acres. The
proposed PUD Plan is providing 25 percent that includes thoroughfare and NC 540 Highway buffers, stream
10 ft wide Type B adjacent to lots
No buffer adjacent to lots that are
None, unless lot is 6,000 sqft or
less, then a 10 ft wide Type B
The Traffic Impact Analysis was completed by Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc (VHB) Traffic Engineers. Please see
The PUD is located east of Green Level Church Road and south of Roberts Road with frontage on both
roadways. NC 540 borders the property to the east.
The existing stop controlled intersections studied include: Green Level Church Road at Jenks Road,
Green Level Church Road at Roberts Road, Green Level West Road at Green Level Church Road, Jenks
Road at Roberts Road/Henniker Street, and Green Level Church Road at Secluded Acres Road.
There are three scenarios: A, B, and C. Scenarios A and B includes 388 single family homes and assumed the
connection to Roberts Road is not acquired. The difference between A and B is that Scenario A assumes two
points of access on Green Level Church Road exclusively while Scenario B also assumes the internal connections
through The Hunt at Green Level Crossing. Scenario C assumes 419 single family homes with the additional
connection to Roberts Road. The PUD is anticipated to generate up to 3,924 new daily trips with 76 inbound
trips and 227 outbound trips in the a.m. peak hour and 240 inbound trips and 11 outbound trips in the p.m.
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
Site Access 1 provides access to Green Level Church Road 3,200 feet south of Roberts Road.
Site Access 2 provides access to Roberts Road 350 feet east of Brincefield Place (future).
Site Access 3 provides access to Green Level Church Road across from Secluded Acres Road.
Gartrell Way (future) through The Hunt at Green Level Crossing provides access to Roberts Road 2,260
feet east of Green Level Church Road.
Brincefield Place (future) through the Hunt at Green Level Crossing provides access to Roberts Road
Please see Attachment 3 for the Traffic Capacity Analysis.
The TIA recommends a warrant study for Jenks Road at Roberts Road/Henniker Street to
determine when a signal may be warranted for the study intersection. Apex staff concurs with

i.b: the recommendation and add the following: The developer shall include a condition of
approval to conduct a warrant study (or studies) when requested by staff and to design and
install the traffic signal as part of the development plan when warranted and prior to final

page.text: 2. The TIA recommends a 50 foot left turn lane exiting Site Access #3, 150-foot left turn lane
southbound on Green Level Church Road, and 50-foot left turn lane northbound on Green
Level Church Road (serving Secluded Acres Road). Apex staff concurs with the
3. The TIA recommends a 50-foot left turn lane exiting Site Access #1 and 150-foot left turn lane
southbound on Green Level Church Road. Apex staff concurs with the recommendations.
4. The TIA recommends a 150-foot left turn lane westbound on Roberts Road serving Site Access
#2. Apex staff concurs with the recommendations.
The TIA recommends no additional improvements to other offsite intersections within the
study area not mentioned in the above items 1-4. Apex staff concurs with no additional
NCDOT maintains Jenks Road, Green Level Church Road, Green Level West Road, Secluded Acres Road, and
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
The proposed PUD Plan is providing access from Green Level Church Road and street stubs from the north and
east (Holt property). The PUD Plan states that sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of the major streets
and one-side for minor streets and cul-de-sacs within the subdivision. A 10-foot wide multi-path is proposed
along Green Level Church Road in compliance with the Apex Pedestrian and Greenway Map.
The proposed PUD Plan parking requirement will be consistent with the UDO.
The project is a participant in the White Oak Basin Master Plan.
The Planning Board reviewed the Residential Master Subdivision Plan at their November 10, 2014 and
The proposed PUD Plan was reviewed by the Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Resources Advisory Commission on
October 28, 2014. The Commission recommended that the developer of the Greenmoor PUD work with other
developers in the area to locate a regional park site. The review was based on 250 single family detached units
X $3,139.38 = $784,995. If the layout or content of the project has changed the developer need to come back
before the PRCR Advisory Commission for review.
The applicant conducted two neighborhood meetings on July 23, 2014 and September 17, 2014. Please see the
The 2030 Land Use Map identifies the proposed site for Medium Density Residential. The proposed rezoning is
consistent with the 2030 Land Use Map.
The proposed PUD Plan is consistent with the Apex Transportation Plan.
The proposed Greenmoor PUD Plan is in compliance with the standards in the UDO.
Staff recommends approval of the Greenmoor PUD Plan, rezoning #14CZ17.

text.b: ANALYSIS STATEMENT OF THE REASONABLENESS OF THE PROPOSED REZONING:

page.text: This proposed rezoning is in keeping with the 2030 Land Use Map for this area which calls for Medium Density
Residential. This rezoning is reasonable because property to the north is zoned Planned Unit Development
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
Medium Density Residential and property to the east and south is residential. The PUD Plan includes
appropriate buffers along NC 540. The rezoning is in the public interest to encourage compatible development
of the property and to increase tax base.
Town Council shall find the PUD-CZ designation demonstrates compliance with the following standards. 2.3.3
The applicant shall propose site-specific standards and conditions that take into account the following
considerations, which are considerations that are relevant to the legislative determination of whether
or not the proposed conditional zoning district rezoning request is in the public interest. These
considerations do not exclude the legislative consideration of any other factor that is relevant to the
1) Consistency with 2030 Land Use Map. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s
appropriateness for its proposed location and consistency with the purposes, goals, objectives, and
policies of the 2030 Land Use Map.
2) Compatibility. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s appropriateness for its proposed
location and compatibility with the character of surrounding land uses.
3) Zoning district supplemental standards. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s
compliance with Sec 4.4, Supplemental Standards, if applicable.
4) Design minimizes adverse impact. The design of the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s
minimization of adverse effects, including visual impact of the proposed use on adjacent lands; and
avoidance of significant adverse impacts on surrounding lands regarding trash, traffic, service delivery,
parking and loading, odors, noise, glare, and vibration and not create a nuisance.
5) Design minimizes environmental impact. The proposed Conditional Zoning District use’s minimization
of environmental impacts and protection from significant deterioration of water and air resources,
wildlife habitat, scenic resources, and other natural resources.
6) Impact on public facilities. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s avoidance of having
adverse impacts on public facilities and services, including roads, potable water and wastewater
facilities, parks, schools, police, fire and EMS facilities.
7) Health, safety, and welfare. The proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use’s affect on the health,
safety, or welfare of the residents of the Town or its ETJ.
8) Detrimental to adjacent properties. Whether the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use is
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
9) Not constitute nuisance or hazard. Whether the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use
constitutes a nuisance or hazard due to traffic impact or noise, or because of the number of persons
who will be using the Conditional Zoning (CZ) District use.
10) Other relevant standards of this Ordinance. Whether the proposed Conditional Zoning (CZ) District
use complies with all standards imposed on it by all other applicable provisions of this Ordinance for
use, layout, and general development characteristics.
The Town Council shall find the PUD-CZ designation demonstrates compliance with the following standards.
In approving a Planned Development (PD) Zoning District designation for a PUD-CZ, the Town Council shall find
the PUD-CZ district designation and PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates compliance with the following standards:
The uses proposed to be developed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ are those uses permitted in Sec.
The uses proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ can be entirely residential, entirely non-
residential, or a mix of residential and non-residential uses. The location of uses proposed by
the PUD-CZ must be shown in the PD Plan with a maximum density for each type of residential
use and a maximum square footage for each type of non-residential use.
The dimensional standards in Sec. 5.1.3, Table of Intensity and Dimensional Standards, Planned
Development Districts may be varied in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ. In no case shall the minimum
side setback for single-family and modular residential be less than five (5) feet. The PUD-CZ
shall demonstrate compliance with all other dimensional standards of the UDO, North Carolina
Building Code, and North Carolina Fire Code.
The development proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ encourages cluster and compact
development to the greatest extent possible that is interrelated and linked by pedestrian ways,
bikeways and other transportation systems. At a minimum, the PD Plan must show sidewalk
improvements as required by the Apex Transportation Plan and the Town of Apex Standard
Specifications and Standard Details, and greenway improvements as required by the Town of
Apex Parks, Recreation, Greenways, and Open Space Plan and the Apex Transportation Plan.
The design of development in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ results in land use patterns that promote
and expand opportunities for walkability, connectivity, public transportation, and an efficient
compact network of streets. Cul-de-sacs shall be avoided unless the design of the subdivision
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
and the existing or proposed street system in the surrounding area indicate that a through
street is not essential in the location of the proposed cul-de-sac, or where sensitive
environmental areas such as streams, floodplains, and wetlands would be substantially
The development proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ is compatible with the character of
surrounding land uses and maintains and enhances the value of surrounding properties.
(b) Off-street parking and loading. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with the standards of
Sec. 8.3, Off-Street Parking and Loading, except that variations from these standards may be permitted if a
comprehensive parking and loading plan for the PUD-CZ is submitted as part of the PD Plan that is determined
to be suitable for the PUD-CZ, and generally consistent with the intent and purpose of the off-street parking
(c) RCA. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with Sec. 8.1.2, Resource Conservation Area,
except that the percentage of RCA required under Sec. 8.1.2 may be reduced by the Town Council by no more
(i) The PD Plan for PUD-CZ includes a non-residential component; or
(ii) The PD Plan for PUD-CZ has an overall density of 6 residential units per acre or more.
(d) Landscaping. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with the standards of Sec. 8.2,
Landscaping, Buffering and Screening, except that variations from these standards may be permitted where it is
demonstrated that the proposed landscaping sufficiently buffers uses from each other, ensures compatibility
with land uses on surrounding properties, creates attractive streetscapes and parking areas and is consistent
with the character of the area. In no case shall a buffer be less than one half of the width required by Sec. 8.2
or ten (10) feet in width, whichever is greater.
(e) Signs. Signage in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall demonstrate compliance with Sec. 8.7, Signs, except that the
standards can be varied as follows if a master signage plan is submitted for review and approval concurrent
(i) The square footage of all permitted permanent ground and wall signage shall be allowed to be
increased by ten (10%) percent of the calculated allowable square footage.
(ii) The names of up to two (2) tenants are allowed per ground sign provided that the name of the
overall development is listed first and is a minimum of fifty (50%) percent larger than the tenant
(f) Public facilities. The improvements standards and guarantees applicable to the public facilities that will
serve the site shall comply with Article 7: Subdivision.
The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates a safe and adequate on-site transportation circulation
system. The on-site transportation circulation system shall be integrated with the off-site
transportation circulation system of the Town. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall be consistent with
Prepared by: June Cowles, Senior Planner
the Apex Transportation Plan and the Town of Apex Standard Specifications and Standard
Details and show required right-of-way widths and road sections. A Traffic Impact Analysis
The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates a safe and adequate on-site system of potable water and
wastewater lines that can accommodate the proposed development, and are efficiently
integrated into off-site potable water and wastewater public improvement plans. The PD Plan
shall include a proposed water and wastewater plan.
Adequate off-site facilities for potable water supply, sewage disposal, solid waste disposal,
electrical supply, fire protection and roads shall be planned and programmed for the
development proposed in the PD Plan for PUD-CZ, and the development is conveniently located
in relation to schools and police protection services.
The PD Plan shall demonstrate compliance with the parks and recreation requirements of Sec.
7.3 Park, Recreation, and Open Space Sites if there is a residential component in the PUD-CZ.
(g) Natural resource and environmental protection. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates compliance with the
current regulatory standards of this Ordinance related to natural resource and environmental protection in Sec.
6.1 Watershed Protection Overlay District, Sec. 6.2 Flood Damage Prevention Overlay District, and Sec. 8.1
(h) Storm water management. The PD Plan shall demonstrate that the post-development rate of on-site storm
water discharge from the entire site shall not exceed pre-development levels in accordance with Sec. 6.1.7 of
(i) Phasing. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ shall include a phasing plan for the development. If development of the
PUD-CZ is proposed to occur in more than one phase, then guarantees shall be provided that project
improvements and amenities that are necessary and desirable for residents of the project, or that are of benefit
to the Town, are constructed with the first phase of the project, or, if this is not possible, then as early in the
(j) Consistency with 2030 Land Use Map. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates consistency with the goals and
policies established in the Town’s 2030 Land Use.
(k) Complies with the UDO. The PD Plan for PUD-CZ demonstrates compliance with all other relevant portions
Craig M. Duerr, PE, LEED AP
Approximately 50.52 acres including 0.52 acres of right-of-way dedication
Section 2.3.4(F)(1)(v) - The existing Greenmoor PUD is a residential planned community
located east of Green Level Church Road, south of Roberts Road, and west of NC-540.
The current zoning is PUD-CZ and is designated on the Town of Apex 2030 Land Use
Map as medium density residential. The approved use is residential, single-family
The proposed amendment adds approximately 50.52 acres for the Morris and Plymale
Tracts to the adjacent Greenmoor PUD. The current zoning for the subject properties is
Rural Residential with a medium density land use designation. The proposed zoning for
the subject properties is PUD-CZ consistent with the Greenmoor PUD. The proposed
amendment is in compliance with the 2030 Land Use Map. The proposal will meet or
exceed all other requirements of the Apex Transportation Plan and the Town of Apex
Standard Specifications and Construction Details. The proposed development
encourages pedestrian connections. The proposal meets the requirements of the Town
of Apex Parks, Recreation, Greenways and Open Space Plan.
Section 2.3.4(F)(1)(v) - The purpose of the approved PUD and the proposed development
is to provide a high-quality medium density residential development in proximity to similar
land uses with connectivity and an efficient street network. The proposed development
pays close attention to avoiding the disturbance of environmentally sensitive areas while
also promoting an internal network of interconnected streets, pedestrian and bicycle
Section 2.3.4(F)(1)(vi) - The existing and proposed residential development is intended
to provide a community that is configured on the property in a way that integrates the new
development into the existing area. The proposed detached single family homes are
similar to what is currently planned for the Greenmooor PUD. The proposed development
will maintain the architectural feel and identity of Greenmoor. The proposed community
will enhance adjoining property values by offering a high-quality product that will
This development will include only residential uses and residential support uses. These
Proposed: Up to 3.56 dwelling units per acre
15 feet for front façade of home
20 feet for front façade of garage
100-foot Type A buffer from single family lots
and no less than 40-foot Type A buffer from
Adjacent to Hunt at Green Level: No buffer
Adjacent to developed property: 10-foot Type B
Adjacent to the Morris Tract: 10-foot Type B

text.b: E. Percentage of Built Upon Area (Impervious Surface)

page.text: Amount and percentage of built upon area allowed: 60%
Amount and percentage of built upon area proposed: Less than 60%
(Exact percentage to be determined at subdivision stage of development.)
The architecture for this community will reflect the residential scale and character of
traditional Apex building styles. Building materials within each residential building type
will be selected from a similar palette but will provide enough variety and diversity to add
individuality and character amongst the product types. Further detailing shall be provided
at the time of site plan submittal.

5. The roof for primary structures (i.e., excluding porches, bay windows, etc.) shall be
6. The garage cannot protrude more than one (1’) foot from either the front façade or

or porch with the inclusion of windows in the garage door and one architectural

7. The side of a corner lot home that is visible from a public street must include two

8. For homes that back up to a perimeter road (i.e., Green Level Church Road or
Roberts Road), the rear windows must include four (4”) inch trim and the rear roof
must include variation in the roofline such that no rear roofline is identical to the
roofline on either side of it. This can be accomplished thru the variation of roof
type, pitch, direction, or height, and/or the addition of features such as dormers or
Parking and loading will comply with all applicable requirements of UDO Section 8.3.
Sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of the major streets and one-side for minor
streets and cul-de-sacs within the subdivision.
Signage will comply with all applicable requirements of the UDO Section 8.7.

text.b: Section 10: Natural Resource and Environmental Data

page.text: Based on aerial photography and visual observations by a qualified landscape
professional, existing vegetation can be characterized in 5 general categories as follows:
Rural Residential – Generally maintained grass areas with several specimen trees
surrounding the existing farm house and sheds
Denuded Areas (RCA#5 and Portion of RCA#7) – Generally bare areas with
underbrush along NC540, Green Level Church Road, and Hickory Mountain Lane
Riparian Buffers (RCA#6) – Generally steep slopes with a mix of Evergreens (Pine,
Cedar) and Hardwoods (Oak, Maple, Poplar, Sweetgum, Ash, etc.) canopy
typically found in the woodlands of the Piedmont and western areas of Wake
County. Very dense understory trees consist of a mix of evergreen and deciduous
(Holly, Wax Myrtle, Dogwood, etc.) with a variety of shrub material.
Interior Wooded Areas – Generally moderate slopes with a mix of Evergreens
(Pine, Cedar) and Hardwoods (Oak, Maple, Poplar, Sweetgum, Ash, etc.) canopy
typically found in the woodlands of the Piedmont and western areas of Wake
County. Very dense understory trees consist of a mix of evergreen and deciduous
(Holly, Wax Myrtle, Dogwood, etc.) with a variety of shrub material.
Open Field Areas – Generally minimal slopes in the interior of the site with a mix
of grasses and sparse tree canopy coverage.
The general health of the plant material ranges from average to above average with good
upper story leafing at the time with some trunk scarring due to wildlife and falling debris.
Some unhealthy specimens were observed, primarily along the wood line edges and
The site is within the Primary Watershed Protection Overlay District.
The site is within the Cape Fear River Basin.
The site is partially located within a Special Flood Hazard Area.
Gross square footage and percent of RCA required: ±12.5 acres (25%)
Gross square footage and percent of RCA provided: ±12.5 acres (25%)
RCA#5 (±2.5 acres) - Street front buffers along Green Level Church Road,
perimeter buffers adjacent to the Holt Tract
RCA#6 (±8.0 acres) - BMPs and riparian buffers along Stream ‘A’ and Stream ‘B’
RCA#7 (±6.0 acres) – Highway buffer along NC540 and perimeter buffers to
Generally, the existing vegetation within the RCA is suitable to meet the criteria in UDO
Sections 8.1.2 and buffer requirements in UDO Section 8.2.6. Some areas such as the
denuded areas will require supplemental plantings to meet opacity standards.
The site does not contain any historic structures as defined by UDO Section 12.2 “Historic
The project shall not increase the post development on-site storm water discharge rate
from that of the pre-development rate for the 1-year, 24-hour and the 10-year, 24-hour
design storms. Stormwater management for the entire site will be managed through the
use of wet detention ponds, constructed wetlands, or other measures in DWQ’s
Stormwater Best Management Practices (BMP) Manual to achieve both quantity and
quality requirements. The preferred standard of care and use of approved BMPs shall be
taken with regards to erosion control and assurance of storm water quality.
The project shall pursue acquisition of land for a regional park facility with other
developers in the area generally consistent with the Parks Recreation, Greenways, and
Open Space Master Plan. If a regional park facility is not secured at the time of recording
plat for the subdivision, a payment-in-lieu is proposed for land dedication. Refer
to PD Plan Z-2 for the general location of one (1) recreation area to be privately
maintained by the Homeowner’s Association. In addition, a 10’ multi-use path shall be
constructed along Green Level Church Road along the property frontage and the portion
of the greenway from Green Level Church Road to Roberts Road that crosses the
northwest portion of the property shall be constructed.
Water and Sanitary Sewer: All lots will be served by Town of Apex public sanitary sewer
and water. Refer to PD Plan Z-4 for conceptual connections to infrastructure within
adjacent development and roadways in accordance with the minimum criteria of the Town
of Apex Standards and Specifications. The utility design shall meet the requirements of
the White Oak Basin Master Plan. In addition, the utility design will be coordinated to
meet the elevations of the casings installed under NC 540 for the future 8-inch waterline
and 10-inch sanitary sewer line connections by others.
Roadways: Internal street design shall conform to Town of Apex Standard Specifications
and Details. The proposed development roadway system will be in accordance with the
Apex Transportation Plan. Dedication of 20-feet of right-of-way will be provided with a
payment-in-lieu for construction of half the ultimate section for Green Level Church Road.
Refer to PD Plan Z-2 for proposed access points and planned/future connectivity. Access
points shown are conceptual and will be finalized at the subdivision plan stage based on
Town of Apex and NCDOT review. It should be noted that the Minor Collector Street
shown along Hickory Mountain Lane will be relocated onto the southern portion of this
PUD with the alignment to be determined at Master Subdivision.
Transportation conditions based on the Town of Apex review of recommendations in the
Traffic Impact Analysis dated August 14, 2014 prepared by VHB amended to include the
Morris and Plymale Tracts are as follows:
1. Site Access #1 shall include a 50-foot left turn lane exiting and 150-foot left turn
lane southbound on Green Level Church Road.
2. Site Access #2 shall include a 150-foot left turn lane westbound on Roberts Road
3. Site Access #3 shall include a 50-foot left turn lane exiting and a 150-foot left turn
lane southbound on Green Level Church Road, and a 50-left turn lane northbound
on Green Level Church Road (serving Secluded Acres Road).
4. Developer shall conduct a warrant study (or studies) for Jenks Road at Roberts
Road/ Henniker Street when requested by Town of Apex staff and subsequently
design and install a traffic signal when warranted and prior to final plat, subject to
Refer to PD Plan Z-3 for proposed phasing. Development in these phases may be built
in any order or combined to accommodate access, utilities and/or grading.

text.b: Section 15: Consistency with Land Use Plan

page.text: The proposed development is consistent with the Land Use Plan’s intent and goals, some
of which include the preservation of Apex’s character, improved economic health,
providing compatibility between new development and existing development; providing
options for affordable housing; the protection of natural resources; the provision of
infrastructure that helps achieve land use and growth management objectives and the
promotion of pedestrian and bicycle usage along with the efficient circulation of traffic.
The proposed development will provide a variety of housing options. Development will
be steered away from the more environmentally sensitive areas on site in order to meet
the goal of preserving and protecting the natural environment.
The Project will comply with all other relevant portions of the UDO.
A residential development is being proposed along Green Level Church Road in Apex,
North Carolina (Figure 1). The development is bordered by Green Level Church Road
on the west and NC 540 on the east. It is expected to be complete by 2018 and consists
Vehicular access to the development is proposed via five driveways – two full
movement driveways along Green Level Church Road and three full movement
driveways along Roberts Road (Figure 2). Two of the driveways on Roberts Road are
planned internal connections with The Hunt at Green Level Crossing development via
The following intersections meet the Town’s requirements for inclusion in the study
area and were analyzed for existing and future conditions, where applicable:
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Roberts Road (SR 1608)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Jenks Road (SR 1601)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Green Level West Road (SR 1605)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Secluded Acres (SR 1783)/Access
Roberts Road (SR 1608) and Future Gartrell Way (future unsignalized)
Roberts Road (SR 1608) and Future Brincefield Place (future unsignalized)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Access #1 (future unsignalized)
The driveway connections to Roberts Road are currently pending internal connection
agreements with The Hunt development and land acquisitions for Access #3.
Therefore, to ensure adequate capacity at the main site driveways, the future year
analysis was conducted under three Build (2018) scenarios, with and without the
internal connections through The Hunt at Green Level Crossing development and
Access #3 on Roberts Road. Therefore, analysis was performed under five scenarios:
Existing (2014), No-Build (2018), Build Scenario A (2018), Build Scenario B (2018), and
The Existing (2014) scenario includes AM and PM peak hour analysis based on the
turning movement count data collected by VHB and taken from study area traffic
studies. Annual growth was applied to the any 2013 volumes to account for growth
between 2013 and 2014. The No-Build (2018) scenario includes Existing (2014) traffic
volumes with site traffic from approved developments and projected annual growth.
The Build Scenario A (2018) scenario includes No-Build (2018) volumes with the
addition of site trips generated by the proposed development accessing the site from
the two access points on Green Level Church Road. The Build Scenario B (2018)
scenario includes No-Build (2018) volumes with the addition of site trips generated by
the proposed development and site access via the internal connections through The
Hunt at Green Level Crossing development and two access points on Green Level
Church Road. The Build Scenario C (2018) scenario includes No-Build (2018) volumes
with the addition of site trips generated by the proposed development with site access
via the internal connections through The Hunt at Green Level Crossing development,
two access points on Green Level Church Road, and the Access #3 on Roberts Road.
Existing analyses were conducted based on current roadway geometrics and turning
movement volumes from the original TIA, study area TIAs, trip generation, and a 2014
PM peak hour count at Jenks Road at Roberts Road. An annual growth of three percent
(3%) was applied to all 2013 traffic volumes to account for growth between 2013 and
As reported in the Summary Level of Service (LOS) table on page vi, all the
intersections in the study area are currently operating at acceptable levels of service
during the AM and PM peak hours.
In the No-Build (2018) scenario, an annual growth rate of three percent (3%) was
applied to the existing traffic to account for the normal growth between the base year
(2014) and the build year (2018). Furthermore, there were several approved
developments in the vicinity projected to be constructed prior to, or at the same time
as the build-out of the proposed development. Site traffic associated with these
approved developments was included in the No-Build (2018) analysis. The
recommended improvements at study area intersections were also included in future
Based on the No-Build (2018) analysis with the mitigations from the approved
developments in place, the signalized study area intersections are expected to operate
at acceptable levels of service (LOS D or better) in both the AM and PM peak hours.
The southbound stop-controlled of Roberts Road at Jenks Road is projected to operate
at LOS F in both the AM and PM peak hours. All other stop-controlled approaches are
expected to operate at acceptable levels of service during the AM and PM peak hours.
The development is proposed to consist of the following land use:
Trip generation was conducted based on the most appropriate corresponding trip
generation code included in the ITE Trip Generation Manual, 9
suggested method of calculation in the NCDOT’s “Rate vs. Equation” Spreadsheet. As a
result, the proposed development is projected to generate 3,924 daily site trips with
303 trips (76 entering, 227 exiting) occurring in the AM peak hour and 381 trips (240
entering, 141 exiting) in the PM peak hour.
If the land acquisition for Access #3 on Roberts Road cannot be acquired then the
density will decrease to 388 single-family homes. This is reflected in Scenario A and
Scenario B. As a result, the proposed development would then be projected to
generate 3,656 daily site trips with 281 trips (70 entering, 211 exiting) occurring in the
AM peak hour and 356 trips (224 entering, 132 exiting) in the PM peak hour.
The generated site trips were generally distributed in accordance with the existing
turning movement counts and land uses.
The Build Scenario A (2018) scenario includes No-Build (2018) volumes with the
addition of site trips generated by the proposed development accessing the site from
the two access points on Green Level Church Road.
The Build Scenario B (2018) scenario includes No-Build (2018) volumes with the
addition of site trips generated by the proposed development and site access via the
internal connections through The Hunt at Green Level Crossing development and two
access points on Green Level Church Road.
The Build Scenario C (2018) scenario includes No-Build (2018) volumes with the
addition of site trips generated by the proposed development with site access via
internal connections through The Hunt at Green Level Crossing development, two
access points on Green Level Church Road, and one access on Roberts Road.
As shown on the Summary LOS table on page vi, all signalized intersections are
projected to operate at acceptable LOS under all Build scenarios during both the AM
and PM peak periods. The southbound stop-controlled of Roberts Road at Jenks Road
is projected to continue to operate at LOS F in both the AM and PM peak hours under
all Build scenarios. All other stop-controlled approaches are expected to operate at
acceptable levels of service during the AM and PM peak hours.
As indicated in the traffic operations analyses, the proposed development is projected
to have slight impact on the traffic operations of the surrounding roadway network
and intersections. The following roadway improvements are recommended:
The traffic analysis indicates that the southbound stop-controlled of Roberts Road is
projected to operate at LOS F in both the AM and PM peak hours. Therefore, the
following mitigation is recommended at this location:
Conduct a future signal warrants study to determine when a signal might be

page.text: The traffic analysis indicates that this intersection is projected to operate acceptably
during the AM and PM peak hours. The following geometric improvements are
recommended at this location to accommodate site traffic:
Construct Access #3 to provide one ingress lane and two egress lanes, an
exclusive left-turn lane with 50 feet full storage and appropriate taper and an
Construct an exclusive left-turn lane on southbound Green Level Church
Road approach with at least 150 feet of full storage and appropriate taper.
Construct an exclusive left-turn lane on northbound Green Level Church
Road approach with at least 50 feet of full storage and appropriate taper.

page.text: The traffic analysis indicates that this intersection is projected to operate acceptably
during the AM and PM peak hours. The following geometric improvements are
recommended at this location to accommodate site traffic:
Construct Access #1 to provide one ingress lane and two egress lanes, an
exclusive left-turn lane with 50 feet full storage and appropriate taper and an
Construct an exclusive left-turn lane on southbound Green Level Church
Road approach with at least 150 feet of full storage and appropriate taper.
The traffic analysis indicates that this intersection is projected to operate acceptably
during the AM and PM peak hours. The following geometric improvements are
recommended at this location to accommodate site traffic:
Construct Access #2 to provide one egress lane and one ingress lane.
Construct an exclusive left-turn lane on the westbound Roberts Road
approach with at least 150 feet of full storage and appropriate taper.

A residential development is being proposed along Green Level Church Road in Apex,
North Carolina (Figure 1). The development is bordered by Green Level Church Road
on the west and NC 540 on the east. It is expected to be complete by 2018 and consists
Vehicular access to the development is proposed via five driveways – two full
movement driveways along Green Level Church Road and three full movement
driveways along Roberts Road (Figure 2). Two of the driveways on Roberts Road are
planned internal connections with The Hunt at Green Level Crossing development via
The following intersections meet the Town’s requirements for inclusion in the study
area and were analyzed for existing and future conditions, where applicable:
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Roberts Road (SR 1608)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Jenks Road (SR 1601)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Green Level West Road (SR 1605)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Secluded Acres (SR 1783)/Access
Roberts Road (SR 1608) and Future Gartrell Way (future unsignalized)
Roberts Road (SR 1608) and Future Brincefield Place (future unsignalized)
Green Level Church Road (SR 1625) and Access #1 (future unsignalized)
VHB Engineering NC, P.C. was retained by Pulte Homes to analyze the potential
traffic impacts of the proposed development and to identify any necessary roadway
improvements. This study summarizes trip generation, distribution, traffic
assignment, and traffic analyses for the proposed development.

text.b: Existing (2014) Lane Configurations and Traffic Control

page.text: Turning movement counts from the original TIA were utilized for the Green Level
Church Road at Roberts Road and Green Level Church Road at Jenks Road
intersections. The Green Level Church Road at Green Level West Road turning
movement count was taken from the Crestmont Residential TIA. The Roberts Road at
Jenks Road turning movement AM peak hour count was taken from the H-7 High
School TIA. A new count by VHB was collected for the PM peak hour to correspond
to the PM peak hour. No count data was available for the Secluded Acres Road
intersection. Turning movement volumes were determine using ITE Trip Generation
Edition and 45 single-family homes. As a result, the proposed road is
projected to generate 41 trips (10 entering, 31 exiting) occurring in the AM peak hour
and 51 trips (32 entering, 19 exiting) in the PM peak hour with the majority projected
to travel to/from the north. Table 1 summarizes the schedule used to obtain the
turning movement data. A detailed summary of the traffic counts can be found in

text.b: Table 1: Weekday Peak Hour Turning Movement Count Schedule

The existing peak hour turning movement volumes are shown in Figure 4. An annual
growth rate of three percent (3%) was applied to the 2013 traffic volumes to account
Peak hour level of service (LOS) measures the adequacy of the intersection geometrics
and traffic controls of a particular intersection or approach for the given turning
volumes. Levels of service range from A through F, based on the average control delay
experienced by vehicles traveling through the intersection during the peak hour.
Control delay represents the portion of total delay attributed to traffic control devices
(e.g., signals or stop signs). Table 2 provides a general description of various levels of

text.b: Table 2: Level of Service Description for Intersections

page.text: Intersection levels of service analyses were performed for the typical weekday AM and
PM peak hours using Synchro/SimTraffic Professional Version 7. A summary of the
findings for the Existing (2014) scenario LOS analysis can be found in Table 3 and the
full Synchro output can be found in Appendix B.
As reported in Table 3, all the intersections in the study area are currently operating at
acceptable levels of service during the AM and PM peak hours.
